facts.text: Appellants, displaced persons from West Pakistan, granted quasi-permanent allotment of 24 standard acres and 15 3/4 units in village Raikot, Ludhiana District in 1949.
Father Sardar Nand Singh entitled to quasi-permanent allotment of 40 standard acres and 5 1/4 units, allotted in village Humbran, same district, 25 miles from Raikot.
Nand Singh applied for consolidation of his lands with appellants' in Raikot; died during pendency, application continued by appellants.
Assistant Custodian rejected consolidation application on ground no land available in Raikot.
Revision petition by appellants dismissed by Additional Custodian.
Appellants preferred revision to Custodian General.
Additional Custodian cancelled allotment of 14 quasi-permanent allottees in village Karodian on ground they were entitled to suburban land and wrongly allotted rural land.
Additional Custodian suo motu cancelled appellants' Raikot allotment of 1949 and allotted Karodian land in substitution, from land released from 14 allottees.
14 Karodian allottees applied for review of cancellation, claiming misapprehension and not entitled to suburban land.
Appellants applied for review of Raikot cancellation.
Additional Custodian recommended restoration to 14 Karodian allottees, admitted wrong allotment; referred back but kept appellants' application pending.
Additional Custodian dismissed appellants' review citing r.14(6) of Evacuee Property Rules (effective July 22, 1952).
Deputy Custodian General revised Additional Custodian's order, restored land to 14 Karodian allottees; appellants' Karodian allotment automatically cancelled.
Appellants moved Deputy Custodian General to call up review and revise October 31, 1952 order cancelling Raikot allotment; respondents 2-4 impleaded (allotted Raikot after cancellation).

Deputy Custodian General dismissed appellants' application, holding jurisdiction taken away by Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 and notification March 24, 1955, relying on Bal Mukund v. State of Punjab.
Notification S.R.O. 697 dated March 24, 1955: Central Government acquired evacuee property allotted under Punjab Govt notification July 8, 1949 (Raikot lands fall under this, not excepted).
Appellants lost possession of Raikot lands before March 24, 1955 notification.

legal_issues.text: Whether Deputy Custodian General had jurisdiction to revise the order cancelling appellants' Raikot allotment after commencement of Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 and notification under s.12 acquiring the property.
Whether s.10 of 1954 Act protects appellants' rights despite loss of possession before acquisition notification.
Whether r.74 of 1955 Rules prevented allotment to respondents 2-4 during pendency.
Scope of powers under s.19 and r.102 of 1954 Act and Rules for cancellation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Challenged correctness of Bal Mukund v. State of Punjab; no specific provision in 1954 Act ceasing jurisdiction of authorities under 1950 Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants' rights protected by s.10 of 1954 Act as allotted under specified 1949 notification; cancellation not on grounds in condition 6.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10 Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954; Condition 6 of 1949 notification

petitioner_arguments.text: r.74 of 1955 Rules prevented transfer/allotment to respondents during pendency before Custodian General.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r.74 Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955

petitioner_arguments.text: s.19(1) subject to rules; r.102 limits cancellation to entrusted property and specified grounds; no entrustment shown.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.17, s.19 Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954; r.102 Rules

respondent_arguments.text: Jurisdiction taken away by ss.12 and 19 of 1954 Act; acquisition notification divests Custodian of title, vests in Central Govt; only managing officer/corporation can cancel allotments.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: ss.12, 19 Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954

court_reasoning.text: Publication of s.12(1) notification extinguishes evacuee interest, vests property in Central Govt; Custodian divested of powers under s.8 of 1950 Act, cannot deal with property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No provision allows Custodian to deal post-vesting; s.19 confers powers only on managing officer/corporation, prevails over s.10 of 1950 Act.

court_reasoning.text: s.10 protects displaced persons in possession at acquisition date; appellants lost possession before March 24, 1955, not entitled.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Holding and possession implicit requirement; Custodian functus officio post-vesting.

court_reasoning.text: r.74 applies to final transfer under s.10, not quasi-permanent allotments under 1950 Act authorities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule in Chapter X for compensation payment, not relevant.

court_reasoning.text: s.19(1) particular provision for cancellation, not requiring entrustment; prevails over general s.17; r.102(d) allows cancellation for any sufficient reason.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Powers confined to managing officers; no one else can cancel post-acquisition.

holdings.text: Deputy Custodian General lacked jurisdiction to revise 1952 cancellation order due to 1954 Act ss.12 and 19 and acquisition notification.
s.10 of 1954 Act requires possession at acquisition; appellants not protected.
r.74 and r.102 do not aid appellants; no bar to respondents' allotment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bal Mukund v. The State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Held powers of Custodian General taken away by 1954 Act, vest in other authority; no provision for continuing proceedings under 1950 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Custodian's powers to allot/cancel evacuee property; divested post-acquisition under 1954 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act, 1954 (44 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Acquisition of evacuee property (s.12); management/disposal of compensation pool (s.16); cancellation powers only for managing officer (s.19); protection for certain allottees in possession (s.10).

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: No transfer during disputes (r.74, not applicable); cancellation grounds for managing officers (r.102).

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; upheld Deputy Custodian General's order rejecting revision of 1952 cancellation, as jurisdiction ceased post-1954 Act acquisition notification; appellants not protected under s.10 due to lack of possession.

key_quotes.text: "the consequence of the publication of the notification by the Central Government under s.12(1) of the Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Act with respect to any property or a class of property would be to divest the Custodian completely of his right in the property"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on loss of jurisdiction post-acquisition.

key_quotes.text: "It is implicit in this section that the displaced person to whom land was allotted held the land and was in possession of such property at the date of the notification."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why s.10 does not protect appellants.

key_quotes.text: "the powers conferred by sub-s.(1) of s.19 of the 1954 Act are to prevail notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force."
key_quotes.speaker: court
